title: Ukiyo-e: Courtesan and Paper Lanterns
transcript:
Narrator: What follows is a conversation between curator Janice Katz and writer and editor at Teen
Vogue Lucy Diavolo.

Janice Katz: This is one that I was really looking forward to showing you. And this is a painting by
Hokusai. This image is just such the ideal, quintessential courtesan who is shown with her really heavy
robes on, her hair done up in this kind of butterfly shape for her bun. All of her hair pins are in there.

Lucy Diavolo: Can we talk about the hair? What goes into a bun like that?

Janice Katz: This particular hairstyle, which is called a yoko-hyogo, and to see it in real life, you get a
sense of how involved it is, the process, many hours sitting there. The kind of sculpting that's involved to
create something like this. And a courtesan would only have her hair washed once a month. So she
would have this elaborate coiffure for the entire month, basically, and trying not to ruin it.

Lucy Diavolo: Are there oils that maintain that, then? Yeah?

Janice Katz: Yeah. So a woman would have her hair oiled a few hours before the whole process started.
And then, a kind of waxy substance is also used, different combs, different ties. The hair pins are made of
tortoiseshell and they would be sticking out kind of radially from her head.

Lucy Diavolo: Oh, so those aren't stray hairs that are coming off? Those are the hair pins?

Janice Katz: They're-- sometimes, a stray hair is shown in these paintings, just in order-- just to show a
level of, oh, this woman is really not as pristine as you think. She's really not as put together as you think.
But I don't see any stray hairs here. <laughs>

Lucy Diavolo: Maybe it's just a little late in the month for the bun.
<laughter>

Janice Katz: So what you're seeing here is a painting that was done very quickly, probably at a party or
some other kind of gathering, when the artist had just a few materials at hand. And so, it's very sketchy.

Lucy Diavolo: Would that have been a common party game, to have your artist friend do a little
elaborate sketch like this?

Janice Katz: If I were at a party with Hokusai, yeah, you better believe I would ask him to do a painting
for me.
<laughter>
